item.title: Putin threatens to escalate war after Russian forces deliver what he called ‘warning strikes.’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sergey Bobylev
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after the conclusion of a regional summit in Uzbekistan on Friday.

item.title: Need Your Money Now? The Markets Aren’t Helping.
item.description: The rout in the stock and bond markets has been especially rough on people paying for college, retirement or a new home. Our columnist has some advice.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Jada Thomas for The New York Times
item.media:description: People who have been saving for a child’s education may have had a shock if they counted on their investments to pay tuition bills for someone in school right now.

item.title: Is New York City Finally Returning to the Office?
item.description: With rising subway ridership and office occupancy, the city’s post-Labor Day return has offered early signs that New York may finally be turning over a new chapter in its recovery.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong and Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mick Magsino, who works in media sales, recently started returning regularly to his office near Times Square after working from home for two and a half years.

item.title: Judge Names Special Master and Keeps Block on Mar-a-Lago Files Inquiry
item.description: The Justice Department is planning to appeal, but the decision is likely to significantly delay its investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of government records.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The special master will have the power to sift through more than 11,000 records the F.B.I. carted away from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida estate.

item.title: Democrats Buoyed by Abortion and Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
item.description: President Biden’s approval rating has climbed to 42 percent, and the number of Americans who believe the country is on the right track has doubled but remains low.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Nate Cohn

item.title: Right After Primary Win, Bolduc Reverses Support for Election Lies
item.description: Don Bolduc, the Republican Senate nominee in New Hampshire, pivoted to the general election, saying he had concluded that the 2020 presidential election “was not stolen.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Don Bolduc, a retired Army general, in Hampton, N.H., on Tuesday night. He is the state’s Republican candidate for Senate.

item.title: At eBay, Lurid Crimes and the Search for Punishment
item.description: The victims of a bizarre cyberstalking operation are trying to hold the chief executive and the culture of the company responsible.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
item.media:credit: Deena So Oteh

item.title: ‘I Ended Up on This Little Island’: Migrants Land in Political Drama
item.description: After long, perilous journeys, Venezuelans unexpectedly found themselves on Martha’s Vineyard, wondering what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan migrants bused from Texas to Washington on Thursday arrived near Vice President Kamala Harris’s residence.

item.title: At Old Coal Mines, the American Chestnut Tries for a Comeback
item.description: Across Appalachia, scientists and foresters are trying to reintroduce a hybrid version, helping to revive damaged land while also bringing back a beloved tree.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao and Maddie McGarvey

item.title: Prince William Moves Into the Spotlight as Heir to the Throne
item.description: Many royal watchers and historians are looking to William and his wife, Kate, who rank high in popularity polls, as the long-term future of the British monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/WPA Pool/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince William in Scotland in May. He has lived a life largely devoid of the controversy, and occasional scandals, that have engulfed his relatives.

item.title: The ‘Queue’ to View Queen Elizabeth’s Coffin Closes Temporarily
item.description: Would-be mourners waiting to pay their respects — known as the Queue — will likely have to wait 24 hours, the British government said, after it reached capacity on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line along the Thames on Thursday. The estimated wait time for people joining it on Friday evening was 24 hours.

item.title: Will the Spiraling Publicity Harm ‘Don’t Worry Darling’ at the Box Office?
item.description: A series of missteps on the promotional trail has raised questions about the film’s viability and its director, Olivia Wilde.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olivia Wilde last month in Los Angeles before she faced questions at a Venice news conference.

item.title: DeSantis’s Martha’s Vineyard Migrants Stunt Shows the Asylum System Is Broken
item.description: America’s immigration system has long been overburdened and outdated.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Humans Have a Long History of Making ‘Very Bad Decisions’ to Save Animals
item.description: As scientists push the frontiers of conservation technology, some of their initiatives raise ethical questions.
item.dc:creator: Tim McDonnell
item.media:credit: Javier Jaén

item.title: The World Now Has a Vision of Ukrainian Victory
item.description: After a successful counteroffensive, Ukrainians are cherishing a moment of happiness.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Gumenyuk
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A mother and son in front of their house in Izium, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Is There Still No Strategy to Defeat Donald Trump?
item.description: Trump-bashing makes us feel good; it doesn’t turn the tide.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: The Story Behind the Averted Rail Strike Is About Employers and Exploitation
item.description: The single best thing President Biden and the Democratic Party could do for workers is to give them the tools and support to build power for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Bettmann, via Getty Images
item.media:description: State troopers were sent to maintain order in Illinois in 1922, when seven of the 16 railroad unions went on strike around the country.

item.title: Nuclear Power Still Doesn’t Make Much Sense
item.description: There’s a lot of new enthusiasm around nuclear power. It isn’t warranted.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Michael Holahan/The Augusta Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Plant Vogtle nuclear energy facility in Waynesboro, Ga.

item.title: Now All Biden Has to Do Is Build It
item.description: Felicia Wong on the hard road ahead to make the president’s plans a lived reality.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Who’s Afraid of the Consumer Price Index?
item.description: There wasn’t really much news in that inflation report.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by ilbusca and Kypros via Getty Images

item.title: Profiting in Congress
item.description: Dozens of lawmakers trade stocks related to their work, and it’s harming trust in the government.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Congress can buy and sell stocks with few restrictions.

item.title: Promise and Peril at the Bottom of the Sea
item.description: How a mining company and a regulator are balancing billions of dollars in profits against the future of the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Will Reid, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachelle Bonja, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polymetallic nodule. Mining companies describe the nodules as a “battery in a rock” because they contain the essential metals for a clean energy economy.

item.title: Vegetarian Recipes for Cozy Days
item.description: Soups, stews and comforting, feel-good foods for after a storm.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Do You Know Someone Who Has Died of Covid Recently? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: New York Times reporters are looking for people who will share the stories and experiences of loved ones who have recently died.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rose River Memorial in Los Angeles, created in 2021 by the artist Marcos Lutyens, honored lives taken by Covid.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Cancels Public Appearances After Falling Ill
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is currently on bed rest under observation by a team of doctors, according to four people familiar with his health situation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Khamenei.Ir, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In a photo made available by his office in June 2022, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is pictured at a ceremony in Tehran.

item.title: Attempts to Ban Books Are Accelerating and Becoming More Divisive
item.description: To mark Banned Books Week, the American Library Association released a report on the rise in censorship efforts: In 2022, there have been attempts to restrict access to 1,651 titles.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many of the books targeted by bans touch on race or L.G.B.T.Q. issues. These books from a high school library in Annandale, N.J., were subject to complaints.

item.title: China’s Discovery of Lunar Mineral Could Add to Fuller View of the Moon
item.description: Scientists found a single crystal of a new phosphate mineral while analyzing lunar basalt particles, which were collected from the moon two years ago by the Chang’e-5 mission.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jin Liwang/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Technicians in Beijing on Dec. 17, 2020, extracting a container with moon samples retrieved by the Chang'e-5 lunar lander.

item.title: Privilege Is in Crisis. Look at Our Elite Private Schools.
item.description: The past few years have witnessed a lot of upheaval in the name of political reckoning. Is the pendulum swinging back to tradition?
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: The current dilemma among high school leaders at Grace Church School is how freely students should dress.

item.title: Do Food Sensitivity Tests Work?
item.description: Food sensitivity tests are becoming increasingly popular. Here’s what the experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Are Smoothies Good For You? It Depends.
item.description: “Just because there’s a leafy green in it doesn’t make it low-calorie.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Can Protein Powders Help Aging Muscles?
item.description: Older adults typically need more protein than younger people. Here’s how to ensure you’re getting enough.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Is Gluten-Free Bread Healthier Than Regular Bread?
item.description: Experts say there are important distinctions to keep in mind.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: The Women of ‘Wakanda Forever,’ the ‘Black Panther’ Sequel
item.description: For the “Black Panther” sequel, Lupita Nyong’o, Danai Gurira, Letitia Wright and their castmates leaned on each other to get through the grief-stricken shoot.
item.dc:creator: Salamishah Tillet
item.media:credit: Simone Niamani Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Danai Gurira, left, Lupita Nyong’o and Letitia Wright have reunited for the new “Black Panther” film, due Nov. 11.
